questions.text: Three female children graphs were plotted on an IAP growth chart, which of them signals growth failure?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only 3 Growth curve 3 show growth failure. The drop to below -2SD is significant and suggested growth failure as it indicates the child is significantly below the normal range.

Highyeild:

Low weight for height or wasting indicates acute malnutrition. High weight for height indicates overweight. Low height for age or stunting indicates chronic malnutrition. Low weight for age indicates acute or chronic malnutrition.

questions.text: A neonate has bilateral chorioretinitis with intraparenchymal calcifications. She also has hydrocephalus. What is the causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Toxoplasma gondi Neonate with bilateral chorioretinitis with intraparenchymal calcifications and hydrocephalus is suggestive of Congenital Toxoplasmosis. The causative agent is Toxoplasma Gondii.

Highyeild:

CONGENITAL TOXOPLASMOSIS TRIAD Chorioretinitis Hydrocephalus Diffuse intracranial calcification. Other features: Hydrops fetalis Intrauterine growth retardation Prematurity Peripheral retinal scars Persistent jaundice

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Trypanosoma causes Trypanosomiasis (Sleeping sickness). Option: Tenia solium causes Taeniasis. Option: D. Congenital cytomegalovirus presents with hepatosplenomegaly, Jaundice, Chorioretinitis, Microcephaly. Intracranial periventricular calcifications are also seen.

questions.text: What is represented by each of the following growth curves?

options.label: D
options.text: 1- Brain, 2- Waldeyer's ring, 3- somatic growth, 4- Testicular growth

questions.correct_answer: D. 1- Brain, 2- Waldeyer's ring, 3- somatic growth, 4- Testicular growth
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1- Brain, 2- Waldeyer's ring, 3- somatic growth, 4- Testicular growth The correct answer is Brain Waldeyer ring Somatic growth Testicular growth

Highyeild:

Curve 1- Neural growth (Brain) attains 90% of the growth by the age of 2 years. Curve 2- The tonsils are collections of lymphatic tissue located within the pharynx. They collectively form a ringed arrangement known as waldeyer ring. Curve 3- Somatic growth shows sigmoid curve. Curve 4- Testicular/Gonadal growth starts during puberty, before that the curve is flat.

questions.text: A mother brought her 2-year-old child to the OPD with complaints of lack of weight gain, abdominal pain on eating, and poor eating habits. The child was advised a gluten-free diet after which there was improvement in the general condition and weight gain. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Celiac disease Child with complaints of lack of weight gain, abdominal pain on eating, and poor eating habits and after advising gluten-free diet there was improvement in the general condition and weight gain, is suggestive of celiac disease.

Highyeild:

CELIAC DISEASE This is an enteropathy caused by permanent sensitivity to gluten in genetically susceptible subjects. It is the most common cause of chronic diarrhea in children over 2 yr of age in North India. The classical presentation is with small bowel diarrhea, growth failure and anemia. A temporal association of diarrhea and introduction of wheat products at weaning may be present. Onset of diarrhea before introduction of wheat products in diet negates a diagnosis of celiac disease. Examination reveals failure to thrive, loss of subcutaneous fat, clubbing, anemia, rickets and signs of other vitamin deficiencies. Diagnosis The main investigations required for making a diagnosis include: Serology- IgA antibody against tissue transglutaminase (tTG) is an ELISA based test, recommended for initial testing of celiac disease. Upper GI endoscopy- It may be normal or show absence of folds or scalloped folds. Multiple (4-6 in number) endoscopic biopsies from the bulb and second/ third part of duodenum should be taken in all cases. Histology- The characteristic histological changes in celiac disease are increased intraepithelial lymphocytes (>30/100 enterocytes), increased crypt length, partial to total villous atrophy, decreased villous to crypt ratio and infiltration of plasma cells and lymphocytes in lamina propria. A and B: Celiac disease. (A) Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy showing scalloping of duodenal folds (arrow); (B) duodenal histology showing total villous atrophy

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Tropical sprue is malabsorption disorder seen as diarrhea , steatorrhea, nutritional deficiency and weight loss. It is diagnosed by a small intestinal biopsy which shows a close resemblance to that in celiac disease but it is not triggered by Gluten. Option: Whipple disease is caused by T. Whipplei. Biopsy shows PAS Positive macrophages. Option: D. Intestinal malabsorption cause poor nutrient absorption.

questions.text: A child presented with failure to thrive and recurrent infections. On examination, tonsils are absent. Further evaluation confirms the deficiency of adenosine deaminase. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency Child with failure to thrive and recurrent infections along with deficiency of adenosine deaminase is suggestive of Severe Combined Immunodeficiency.

Highyeild:

SEVERE COMBINED IMMUNODEFICIENCY Adenosine deaminase deficiency is one of the major cause of SCID. It is also called as Glanzmann-Riniker syndrome. SCID patients are usually affected by severe bacterial, viral or fungal infections early in life and often presents with interstitial lung disease, chronic diarrhea and failure to thrive.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is due to deficiency of HGPRT enzyme. It presents with hyperuricemia, self-mutilation behaviour. Option: B. Ataxia telangiectasia is neurodegenerative genetic disease causing poor coordination and small dilated blood vessels. It is due to ATM gene mutation. Option: D. Friedrich ataxia involves posterior column, pyramidal and spinocerebellar tract. It presents with cardiomyopathy, optic atrophy and diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chiari type 1 Above MRI image shows a downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum which is characteristic of Chiari Type I malformation.

Highyeild:

CHIARI I MALFORMATION It is the more common type. There is downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. It may be associated with syringomyelia. CHIARI II MALFORMATION Displacement of the medulla, fourth ventricle and cerebellar vermis through the foramen magnum. It is almost always associated with myelomeningocele.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: B. Dandy-Walker malformation is a developmental anomaly characterized by cystic dilatation of fourth ventricle, hypoplasia of cerebellar vermis, an enlarged posterior fossa and upward displacement of the cerebellum. Option: C. MR angiography in the vein of Galen malformation shows enlarged midline venous structure with multiple arteriovenous communications leading to aneurysmal dilatation. Option: D. Above image is not corpus callosum agenesis. Below is the image showing corpus callosum agenesis.
